review.title: How Easy is it to Learn a Controlled Natural Language for Building a Knowledge Base?
review.abstract: Recent developments in controlled natural language editors for knowledge engineering (KE) have given rise to expectations that they will make KE tasks more accessible and perhaps even enable non-engineers to build knowledge bases. This exploratory research focussed on novices and experts in knowledge engineering during their attempts to learn a controlled natural language (CNL) known as OWL Simplified English and use it to build a small knowledge base. Participants' behaviours during the task were observed through eye-tracking and screen recordings. This was an attempt at a more ambitious user study than in previous research because we used a naturally occurring text as the source of domain knowledge, and left them without guidance on which information to select, or how to encode it. We have identified a number of skills (competencies) required for this difficult task and key problems that authors face.

sections.heading: 3.1 OWL Simplified English
sections.text: OWL Simplified English (OSE), [15], is a relatively formless language in which each sentence expresses an OWL statement and entity names (for individuals, classes, and properties) are recognized by their relationship to a handful of common English keywords such as "the," is, "has," and "a," with minimal classification of content words. It is up to the author to decide whether to create text that would be recognizable or intelligible as natural English. Thus, "A because is an of." in the sentence "A dog is an animal." would also be a valid OSE sentence, meaning that the class "because" is interpreted as a class name. "3OSE" is relatively unlimited when limited with other CNs that require vocabulary. "

sections.heading: 3.2 SWAT Editing Tool
sections.text: The editing tool4 used in this study was developed for the SWAT project5, as described in Power [16]. It implements OSE [15] and dynamically builds OWL statements as the user types OSE sentences. Its predictive interface provides sentence patterns (as full sentences or subsentences) and feedback on the OWL statement under construction. As the user types, text is analyzed character by character and automatically colored brown for class names, purple for individuals, blue for properties, and green for literals. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: The OWL experts seemed to master OSE quickly and easily produced small ontologies. Of course, newcomers had difficulties and needed more guidance, such as examples of syntactically correct sentences. Alternative interfaces such as WYSIWYM [14] have some success with newcomers at the expense of the freedom to type text as in a conventional editor. Dialog systems currently under development, such as the WhatIf! project [13], could provide a way forward. If a system had the ability to respond with intelligent and appropriate questions and comments about the possibly unintended effects of input knowledge, it could even allow newcomers to gain an insight into formal semantics and thus construct logically consistent KBs.
